text.p: - Slovenia's prime minister-designate Janez Drnovsek said he expected parliament to approve his new cabinet on Thursday, almost three months after inconclusive November 10 general elections.

- Government coalition comprising centre-left Liberal Democrats, former communists the United List, Desus party representing pensioners and Nationalist Party expects governmental line-up to be approved by parliament in today's vote.
- A civil society group will hold a protest rally in front of parliament, claiming that the government's line-up which is due to be approved today is illegal.
- Slovenian branch of Bank Austria opened a subsidiary in the coastal town of Koper. The bank plans to open subsidiaries in Celje and Maribor.
- The Trbovlje power plant will be closed and replaced by another source of electricity by 2003, the environment ministry said.

- Pharmaceutical producer Krka plans to start construction of a factory worth $25 million in Sentjernej, 60 km (37 miles) south of Ljubljana next year. Krka also plans to open factories in Poland, Croatia and Russia.
- Liberal Democrats and United List of Social Democrats, the former communist party, signed a formal coalition agreement on Wednesday.
- The country's privatisation agency said that 1,347 companies have already been privatised, while another 906 are still in the process.
